RUSSIA.Balances ofthe formerRussianGovernment,(previous reference:Cabinet 34(27), Con-clusion l,j3, The Chancellor of the Exchequer made astatement to the Cabinet-in regard to certainfunds held in London banks to the credit of thelate Imperial and Provisional Russian Government,now amounting to upwards of 5,000,000, on which,under Article 10 of the Russian Trade Agreement,the Soviet Government had undertaken tp make noclaims, Mr Churchill pointed out that, now thatthe Russian Trade Agreement had been terminated,the Soviet Government are no longer debarred fromclaiming this money, and that, as they have been recognised by His Majesty's Government as thede Jure. Government of Russia, such a claim would very likely succeed in the Eritish Courts, Thewhole of these funds had been supplied by Britishtaxpayers for the purpose of enabling the ImperialRussian Government to carry on the War, Theyformed part of the assets of the former RussianGovernment, and it was essential that they shouldnot be allowed to fall into Soviet hands, - he asked for the appointment of a Cabinet Committeeto consider what action should be taken.The Cabinet agreed -That a Cabinet Committee, composed as follows -The Chancellor of the Exchequer(in the Ghcir),The Lord Chancellor,The Secretary of State for India,The President of the Board of Trade,The Attorney-General bnonld meet to consider the questionof the balances of the former RussianGove.rnm.erj1;., and, in addition, toadvise the'Cabinet as to whether thoSoviet Government, which had been recognised as the de jure. The Cabinet were informed of the followingMotions on the suhj-debt of the Reform of theHouse of Lords, which had been put down forMonday, June 20th:-The Viscount PitzAlan of Derwent Tocall attention to the question of the reform of the House of Lords, and tomove that in view of the long standingdeclarations of Ministers that reform of the Second Chamber of the Legisla-ture is of urgent importance to thepublic service, this House would welcome a reasonable measure limitingand defining membership of the house and dealing with the defects whichare inherent in certain of the pro-visions of the Parliament Act.The Duke of Marlborough mo move (as an amendment to the above motion) to leaveout all the words after "that" and to add "in view of the failure of any scheme of House of Lords Reform to arouse interest, this House regardsfurther discussion of the question as Inopportune and unprofitable".The Lord Sudley (E.Arran) To move(as an amendment to the above motion)after "Parliament Act" to add "butthat in view of the omission of anymention of so grave an alteration inthe Constitution from the officialprogramme of His Majesty's present government at the last General Elec-tion, it would be contrary to Parlia-mentary practice to introduce any measure dealing with the matter until after the electorate has had, anopportunity of expressing its views."The Lord Privy Seal informed his colleagues the course that, subject to their consent^ he proposed toadopt in the Debate was that at an early stageone of the members of the Government in theHouse of. Lords should make a statement of thepolicy of the Government as set forth in theCabinet Minutes referred to in the margin.Although the decisions of the Cabinet fell very far short of what he himself considered neces-sary, as Leader of the Government in the .Houseof Lords he would be bound to speak in the Debate, He proposed to say that he personallydid not regard the Government's proposals as acomplete solution of the question, but ratheras a fulfilment of the Government'a pledgesand as a step.in the right direction.In the course of the discussion at theCabinet^ suggestions were made to the effectthat the Government speakers should indicatethat,In a modest scheme such as that now contem-plated, a considerable element of hereditary peers would necesserily remain, and that therewere s^ssse^ objections to any system of popularelection for members of the Upper House.The Cabinet agreed (a) To approve generally the courseoutlined by the Lord Privy' Seal:(b) That the members of the CabinetIn the House of Lords should meeton THURSDAY, JUNE 16, at about -4r p.m, to discuss the procedure in the Debate.
